citations.narrative:
Four 30-day-old Maine Coon kittens born on 3/19/24 were transported by the facility on 4/18/24 and taken to the Nashville
Exotic Expo on 4/20/24 where three of the kittens were sold.
Kittens transported or sold in commerce before 8 weeks of age may experience additional stress and have an increased
risk of health problems. Ensure kittens sold or transported in commerce are at least 8 weeks of age (56 days) and have
been weaned.
To be corrected from this day (7/16/24) forward.

One 10-day-old bobcat kitten born on 4/8/24 was transported by the facility on 4/18/24 for the Nashville Exotic Expo and
sold on 4/21/24.
Nondomestic cats of this age do not have a fully functioning immune system and are unable to thermoregulate which puts
them at greater risk of illness or death. Nondomestic cats must be protected from harm by not transporting or selling them
if they are 4 weeks (28 days) or younger in age.
To be corrected from this day (7/16/24) forward.

The facility set up a table at the Nashville Exotic Expo held the weekend of April 20-21, 2024. The facility brought multiple
young and immature animals to the show for the purposes of exhibition and possible sale. These animals included one
bobcat that was less than 2 weeks old, 4-week-old Maine Coon kittens, 2-week-old grey foxes, 3-week-old silver foxes, 5-
week-old servals, 3.5-week-old fennec foxes, and a 5-week-old pale fox. The facility attended the event all day from 9am
to 5pm on 4/20/24 but did not attend the show on Sunday with the animals based on the Saturday event.
The noisy, stressful, air-conditioned cool environment plus the length of time at the show is not conducive to a healthy
environment for newborn animals that are unable to thermoregulate. Young and immature animals do not have a fully
functioning immune system needed to fight off disease and infection and are exposed to a large number of people and
other animals in a show environment. The facility shall ensure that young or immature animals are not exhibited for
periods of time or in a manner which would be detrimental to their health or well-being.
To be corrected from this day (7/16/24) forward.

There is a section of enclosures housing three black and white ruffed lemurs and four red ruffed lemurs that does not
have a perimeter fence around it.
An insufficient or incomplete perimeter fence can allow unwanted animals or people to enter the facility and potentially
harm the animals within. The perimeter fence must be constructed so that it protects nonhuman primates by restricting
unauthorized humans, and animals the size of dogs, skunks, and raccoons from going through it or under it and having
contact with the nonhuman primates. It must be of sufficient height (at least six feet high) to keep unwanted species out. It
must be of sufficient distance (at least three feet) from the outside wall or fence of the primary enclosure to prevent
physical contact between animals inside the enclosure and outside the perimeter fence.
To be corrected by July 31, 2024.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
n

narrative:
2.130 
   
Minimum age requirements. 
Four 30-day-old Maine Coon kittens born on 3/19/24 were transported by the facility on 4/18/24 and taken to the Nashville 
Exotic Expo on 4/20/24 where three of the kittens were sold.  
Kittens transported or sold in commerce before 8 weeks of age may experience additional stress and have an increased 
risk of health problems. Ensure kittens sold or transported in commerce are at least 8 weeks of age (56 days) and have 
been weaned.  
To be corrected from this day (7/16/24) forward. 
2.131(b)(1) 
   
Handling of animals. 
One 10-day-old bobcat kitten born on 4/8/24 was transported by the facility on 4/18/24 for the Nashville Exotic Expo and 
sold on 4/21/24. 
Nondomestic cats of this age do not have a fully functioning immune system and are unable to thermoregulate which puts 
them at greater risk of illness or death. Nondomestic cats must be protected from harm by not transporting or selling them 
if they are 4 weeks (28 days) or younger in age. 
To be corrected from this day (7/16/24) forward. 
2.131(c)(3) 
   
Handling of animals. 
The facility set up a table at the Nashville Exotic Expo held the weekend of April 20-21, 2024. The facility brought multiple 
young and immature animals to the show for the purposes of exhibition and possible sale. These animals included one 
bobcat that was less than 2 weeks old, 4-week-old Maine Coon kittens, 2-week-old grey foxes, 3-week-old silver foxes, 5-
week-old servals, 3.5-week-old fennec foxes, and a 5-week-old pale fox. The facility attended the event all day from 9am 
to 5pm on 4/20/24 but did not attend the show on Sunday with the animals based on the Saturday event. 
The noisy, stressful, air-conditioned cool environment plus the length of time at the show is not conducive to a healthy 
environment for newborn animals that are unable to thermoregulate. Young and immature animals do not have a fully 
functioning immune system needed to fight off disease and infection and are exposed to a large number of people and 
other animals in a show environment. The facility shall ensure that young or immature animals are not exhibited for

periods of time or in a manner which would be detrimental to their health or well-being.  
To be corrected from this day (7/16/24) forward. 
3.78(d) 
   
Outdoor housing facilities. 
There is a section of enclosures housing three black and white ruffed lemurs and four red ruffed lemurs that does not 
have a perimeter fence around it.  
An insufficient or incomplete perimeter fence can allow unwanted animals or people to enter the facility and potentially 
harm the animals within. The perimeter fence must be constructed so that it protects nonhuman primates by restricting 
unauthorized humans, and animals the size of dogs, skunks, and raccoons from going through it or under it and having 
contact with the nonhuman primates. It must be of sufficient height (at least six feet high) to keep unwanted species out. It 
must be of sufficient distance (at least three feet) from the outside wall or fence of the primary enclosure to prevent 
physical contact between animals inside the enclosure and outside the perimeter fence.  
To be corrected by July 31, 2024. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.

species.common: RED FOX (INCLUDES SILVER FOX & CROSS FOX)
